author: Staff Reporter
text:
Students of JNU, who burnt sections of the Manusmriti at Sabarmati Dhaba in the campus on March 8, have questioned the university administration on what it found wrong in their action.

Responding to show-cause notices served on them by the university to “explain their position” on why they burnt copies of the ancient legal text, at least three students have said there was “nothing wrong” in their action.

“What is wrong in burning copies of Manusmriti ? Protesting against anything which we find derogatory is our right. Also this is not the first time that copies of that book have been burnt by us,” one of the students said in his response. Varsity sources said at least two other students have filed similar replies to the notice.

The students have also pointed out that the notices do not mention the “offence” for which they have been asked to give an explanation.

Almost a month after a controversial event organised against the hanging of Parliament attack convict Afzal Guru was reported from the university, five ABVP rebels, joined by Left-backed All India Students Association (AISA) and Congress-affiliated National Students Union of India (NSUI) burnt sections of Manusmriti text at Sabarmati Dhaba, which was also the venue of the earlier event.

The JNU administration had issued notices to five students asking them to explain their “position”.
title: ‘What is wrong in burning Manusmriti?’
